content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see approximately seven sections of tissue arranged in a line. Based on their morphology and the clinical context of colorectal cancer, these are most likely lymph nodes. They vary in size and shape, and are composed of dense, basophilic (purple) lymphoid tissue. The surrounding tissue is pale, likely representing adipose and connective tissue. The fourth node from the left appears to have an area of interest at its periphery.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my primary task for these sections is to identify metastatic cancer. Tumor cells from a primary colorectal cancer would typically travel through lymphatic vessels and first deposit in the subcapsular sinus, which is located just under the capsule at the periphery of the lymph node. The green box is positioned on the periphery of the fourth lymph node from the left. At low power, this area shows a subtle irregularity and a different color/texture compared to the rest of the lymph node cortex, raising suspicion for metastatic involvement. Therefore, I would zoom in to examine the cellular details in this specific region. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to systematically evaluate every lymph node on the slide for evidence of metastasis. The green box is centered on the fourth lymph node from the left. I would zoom into this area as part of my routine, sequential examination of the nodes. The goal is to assess the overall architecture of this specific node at higher magnification, looking for any disruption of the normal structure (e.g., replacement of lymphoid tissue by tumor) or the presence of atypical, non-lymphoid cells that would suggest metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would be systematically examining each lymph node on the slide. The zoom is on the sixth lymph node from the left. I've zoomed into the periphery of this node because the subcapsular sinus, located just under the capsule, is the most common initial site for metastatic tumor cells to deposit after arriving via afferent lymphatic vessels. A high-magnification view is essential to carefully inspect this area for small clusters of atypical cells (micrometastasis) that might be missed at low power. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is the smallest and final lymph node in the series. It is critical to meticulously examine every single lymph node, regardless of size, to accurately determine the N stage. The area selected by the green box appears to be on the periphery of this small lymph node, a common location for early metastatic deposits to be found, particularly in the subcapsular sinus or the surrounding pericapsular tissue. There seems to be a small, dark, discrete focus separate from the main lymphoid aggregate which is suspicious and requires high-power examination. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is part of a systematic examination of all submitted lymph nodes. This particular lymph node, being one of the largest, is a high-priority target for evaluation. At low power, I can appreciate some mottling or architectural disruption within the otherwise dense lymphoid tissue. There are paler, more eosinophilic (pinkish) areas that break up the uniform sea of purple lymphocytes. These areas are suspicious for metastatic carcinoma, which often presents as nests or glands of cells with more cytoplasm, appearing paler than the surrounding lymphoid cells. The goal is to magnify this region to confirm or rule out the presence of tumor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the junction of the lymph node parenchyma (dense purple cells on the right) and the surrounding pericapsular adipose tissue (pale tissue on the left). Within the capsule and subcapsular sinus, there are distinct nests and clusters of atypical cells. These cells are much larger than the surrounding small, dark lymphocytes. They have abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm and large, irregular, hyperchromatic nuclei. Some clusters appear to form poorly-defined glandular structures. These are definitive features of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense population of lymphoid cells. The key feature is the presence of multiple lymphoid follicles, some of which show paler centers, consistent with reactive germinal centers. This pattern is indicative of reactive follicular hyperplasia, a benign process. The tissue is composed predominantly of small, dark lymphocytes. At the top of the image, perinodal adipose tissue is visible. I do not see any clear evidence of metastatic carcinoma (e.g., atypical glands, nests of tumor cells, or single malignant cells) in this specific field of view. My impression is that this area represents a reactive, benign lymph node. However, a definitive conclusion requires examining the entire node and all other nodes on the slide.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the edge of a lymph node adjacent to perinodal adipose tissue. The lymphoid tissue consists of a dense population of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. The subcapsular sinus region does not contain any definite nests of metastatic carcinoma. There is a small, smudgy, darker aggregate of cells near the capsule, which could be an artifact, tangential sectioning, or a focus of sinus histiocytosis, but it lacks the clear cytological atypia of malignancy. My impression of this specific field is a benign/reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis. I would proceed to examine the rest of this node and the other nodes on the slide to make a final determination.
This is ROI 4. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I see a portion of a lymph node on the left, characterized by a dense population of lymphocytes. The surrounding tissue is pink, fibro-adipose (fatty and fibrous) tissue, typical for the tissue around a lymph node. The most significant finding is a small, distinct, and well-circumscribed cluster of dark purple (hyperchromatic) cells floating in this pericapsular tissue. These cells are arranged in a small nest, appear atypical, and are not lymphocytes. My impression is that this is a small focus of metastatic adenocarcinoma. This would be classified as either an Isolated Tumor Cell (ITC) cluster (if ≤0.2mm) or a micrometastasis (if >0.2mm and ≤2.0mm). This finding confirms that this lymph node is positive for metastasis.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the normal lymph node architecture is effaced and infiltrated by malignant glands. I see back-to-back and irregularly shaped glands composed of atypical epithelial cells. These cells are pleomorphic, with enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm. They are clearly distinct from the surrounding dense population of small, dark lymphocytes. The morphology of these infiltrating glands is consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma, very likely of colorectal origin. There also appears to be some associated desmoplastic stromal reaction and focal necrosis. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic adenocarcinoma.
